trial_identification.studytitle: Tropisetron versus metoclopramide for nausea and vomiting in the emergency department: a randomised, double blinded, clinical trial
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A randomised double blind clinical trial to compare the efficacy of tropisetron and metoclopramide in decreasing nausea and vomiting in the emergency department

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Other diseases of the mouth, teeth, oesophagus, digestive system including liver and colon

interventions.interventions: An intravenous bolus of 5mg of tropisetron (over 30 seconds)
interventions.comparator: An intravenous bolus of 10mg of metoclopramide (over 30 seconds)

primaryOutcome.outcome: Nausea score (0-100) on a visual analogue scale

secondaryOutcome.outcome: requirement for rescue medication (additional drugs to control nausea and/or vomiting) as determined by the treating medical staff (not by nausea score)

Side effects including drowsiness (measured using a 5 point sedation scale), dystonic reactions (determined clinically by the treating the clinicians) and akathisia (measured using the Prince Henry Hospital Akathisia Rating Scale.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Patients who have presented to the emergency department for treatment; age 18 years or more; nausea and/or vomiting that requires drug treatment as determined by the treating physician
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Refusal to participate; Migraine (metoclopramide sedation confers an advantage); Inability to co-operate or consent due to debility, significant illness, language barriers, altered consciousness (as determined by the emergency department or study staff); Known allergy or hypersensitivity to tropisetron or metoclopramide; Intoxication (alcohol, substance abuse); Pregnancy; Previous administration of antiemetic within 24 hours

trial_design.concealment: A note containing each patient's allocation will be inside a sealed envelope inside each study pack.
trial_design.designfeatures: Emergency department staff will open the allocation envelope, draw up the allocated drug and inject itinto the patient. However, these staff will not disclose the nature of the drug administered and take not part in the patient management of data collection.

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Tropisetron has been shown to be more efficacious than metioclopramide in the post-operative and chemotherapy settings. Both drugs are widely used in the emergency department setting. However, no study has been undertaken to compare the drugs in the emergency department setting.
